content.description:
Climb through or around blocks and a small roof to a bolted anchor. Several variations available ranging from 5.3 - 5.6. The face to the left and the slot to the right offer interesting climbing.

 This route has clearly been climbed many times and likely has an "official" name and grade. Hopefully someone with local knowledge can update this listing.
content.location: There are two bolts to the left of the gully. As of this writing, these are the leftmost bolts available on the cliff.

content.description: Climb straight up the face to gain the small ledge. From the ledge, continue straight up with some delicate face climbing. The crux is near the top.
content.protection: There are two glue-in bolts at the top of route for your anchor.
content.location: From the climber's left to right, this is the 7th set of glue-in bolts at the top of the crag.

content.description: Climb the parallel diagonal cracks to gain the horizontal crack. Then pull through and continue on up.
content.protection: There are two glue-in bolts at the top of route for your anchor.
content.location: From the climber's left to right, this is the 4th set of glue-in bolts at the top of the crag.

content.description: Tuesday Dusk has fun climbing on much chunkier rock than the route to its right with a lot of holds. It's trickier than it looks. It has a headwall before the anchors that is very slightly overhung but with good holds.
content.protection: There are glue-in anchors at the top for easy toprope setup.
content.location: It is the route just left of Tuesday Night Second.

content.description: This goes left to right or right to left. Stay low, and traverse the cliff. There are a couple tricky spots. It is the best line here as far as Iâ€™m concerned.
content.location: A left to right direction is recommended.

content.description:
This is another of the best parts of the Waite's Mount Traverse, and you've got the option to go right or left.

 Right: look for the small, right-leaning ramp, and bear hug the big Tetris feature above, working to the right around the bulge and then into the dihedral with a finish onto a pedestal. Take a bow!

 Left: staring on a pedestal and moving into the dihedral, around the bulge, some fun face moves on the Tetris blocks with smeared feet below, ending with a topout or downclimb to your pad.
content.protection: Several pads to cover the distance, but you're never the high off the ground while doing the right climb.
content.location: Look for the first large dihedral as you walk down the hill, and the crag is on your left. The pedestal stone is the start for the left climb and the right-leaning ramp is the start for the right climb.

content.description: Follow the dark, black stain on the right with a bunch of pockets and 2-3 finger blocks, and finish on a deep crack just above the large, white blob.

Dad-Rocrag is on super enjoyable, high quality rock you stick to like a frog. Stand start at the bottom of a triangle, the top 3rd of which has pronounced features on the otherwise flatter rock on either side of it. Enjoy bunch of solid horns and blocky knobs as you climb past some old white graffiti and a very stable but high topout.
content.location: To the right of A Hint of Spice and to the left of red paint streak, look for an orange triangle with old white graffiti at the top. There's a small, right-leaning ramp for your start.

content.description: Follow the obvious, deep, sideways V crack to the right of 1st Diaper Change. I've pulled most of the vegetation, but the crack is pretty deep and super bomber, and there's still some dirt in there. Keep your feet on the shelf as you swap to underclings to finish it up.

This is another way to enjoy the little arch below the coffin roof, with a direct start of Baby Beluga. It gets a little spicy once you get your feet above the top of the arch, but you get solid feet for the topout.
content.location: This is a direct start on the arch from Baby Beluga.

climbs.name: Can They Mow The Lawn Yet?

content.description: This does not have as great feet or as deep of a ridge as Diaper Rash, but it is still fun. Follow the ridge that becomes a little more prominent at about shoulder height from a standing start.

The rock makes a little open book face about 6 feet off the ground with a nice ledge. Start with an easy bottom move up to the arete, and move into the open book face when it gets blank to keep it a V0. Finish on the face for a single V3 move.
content.location: It is the furthest left when walking down the approach road. There isn't a great walkoff. I would like to see the town pull a ton of the weeds above so you could walk around.

content.description:
This is one of the best parts of the Waite's Mount Traverse with a highball topout. I've found the right to left is the most fun, especially if you do a double gaston while in the arch.

 Stand start just to the right of the arch, move through the arch to the left onto a funky, blocky knob, and then go up and out to a rather stable set of foot holds for a topout.
content.location: Look for the subtle, head high arch that's way below a coffin-sized roof. If you've hit the dihedral just before A Hint of Spice, you've gone too far.

content.description: Start by climbing onto the small ledge, and then work your way straight up following the vertical cracks. There are plenty of good feet to find as you climb. The crux is at the top.
content.protection:
There are two glue-in bolts at the top of route for your anchor.

 There are plenty of placements for stoppers, as well as a few cam placements (0.3 - 3 Camalots). The rock quality is questionable in places, so be aware if you're placing gear.
content.location: From the climber's left to right, this is the 3th set of glue-in bolts at the top of the crag.

content.description: This is a very fun and obvious blocky shelf. Start directly below, and work the shelf to the top.
There are numerous routes/problems along the wall.
